title: Dynamic Role Allocation Study
assumption: Current AI-human collaboration uses static role assignments
hypothesis: Dynamic role allocation systems will produce superior research outcomes compared to static role assignments
evaluationPlan: Between-subjects ANOVA comparing static vs dynamic conditions, regression analysis of role allocation triggers
implications: Fundamental shift toward adaptive collaborative systems
relatedWork: Builds on Amershi et al. 2019 guidelines and mixed-initiative interaction principles
successCriteria: 15-20% improvement in research quality scores, higher user satisfaction

title: Iterative vs Sequential Collaboration
assumption: Most AI-human collaboration follows sequential handoff patterns
hypothesis: Iterative feedback mechanisms will demonstrate higher research velocity and quality than sequential workflows
evaluationPlan: Mixed-effects modeling with time-series analysis of hypothesis evolution
implications: New paradigm for structuring long-term collaborative relationships
relatedWork: Extends Lee et al. 2022 work on interleaved collaboration
successCriteria: Higher research velocity and more sophisticated hypothesis development
notes: 40 research teams, original research projects, 8-week duration

title: Shared Context Management Study
assumption: AI-human collaborations have limited mechanisms for maintaining shared context
hypothesis: Persistent shared context will improve collaboration consistency and enable cumulative learning
evaluationPlan: Longitudinal growth curve modeling with content analysis of cross-session references
implications: Enhanced effectiveness of long-term collaborative relationships
relatedWork: Addresses gaps in collaborative memory research
successCriteria: Strongest cumulative learning effects in context-active condition
notes: 50 participants, 6 weeks with 3 sessions per week

title: Metacognitive Collaboration Protocol
assumption: Collaboration processes are typically implicit and unreflected
hypothesis: Explicit metacognitive strategies will improve coordination and reduce friction
evaluationPlan: Event analysis of friction incidents with process mining and longitudinal modeling
relatedWork: Novel application of metacognitive strategies to human-AI collaboration
successCriteria: Lowest friction and highest satisfaction in collaborative-metacognitive condition
notes: 45 participants, systematic review tasks, explicit process reflection

title: Task-Specific Collaboration Optimization
assumption: One-size-fits-all collaboration approaches are used across different task types
hypothesis: Task-specific collaboration patterns will outperform general-purpose frameworks
evaluationPlan: Mixed-effects ANOVA with task type and condition factors, performance prediction modeling
implications: Task-specific optimization of human-AI collaborative systems
relatedWork: First systematic study of task-specific collaboration optimization
successCriteria: Consistent outperformance of task-optimized over general conditions
notes: 80 participants across 4 task types, 3-week duration per task
